PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is the difference between a kutcha house and a pucca house?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The difference between Kutcha house and pucca house is that kutcha houses are made from bamboo, mud, grass, leaves and straw while the pucca houses are made of bricks, cement, tiles, marbles, iron and glass. Kutcha houses are not very strong and so, last for a few days, while pucca houses are strong, so, last for a long time.

Many people live in these buildings. They have all the modern facilities such as a shopping centre, community hall, park, good security system and parking area.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: We eat food with our family everyday. It also forms a key part of every special occasion. Wedding, birthday, anniversaries and religious festivals are celebrated by eating meals together with the relatives and friends

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: When the crop is ripe, it has to be cut when farmers cut their crops, it is known as harvesting. It is done by sickless or machines. Winnowing is removal of husk after threshing

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Shy animals are those animals which run away when we go near them. They don't want to be friendly with us. Examples birds, squirrels, deer, bears, monkeys and wild horses

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: How do honeybees produce honey?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Flowes produce nectar Honeybees visit the flowers to get this nectar. They consume pollen grains along with nectar. Once their stomach gets filled up, they spit out the nectar into the cells of their hire. After a few days, this nectar turns into honey

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Ducks have a strong and spoon-shaped beak because they use their beak to take in muddy water which often contains insects, worms, etc

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Who are known as ‘birds of prey’? Give any two examples.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Birds of prey are those birds which attack and eat small animals. They have very strong and sharp claws which help them to catch and hold their prey firmly. e.g. eagle, hawk, vulture and owls

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What are temporary and permanent teeth?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The first tooth appeas in a child when he is about five months. By the age of six, the child has a set of 20 teeth. These teeth are called temporary teeth. When a child is seven years old, he/she starts losing the milk teeth. As the milk teeth fall out, new teeth grow in their place. These new teeth are known as permanent teeth

We take care of our teeth in the following ways, •	by rinsing our mouth with water, after every meal, •	by using a flossing thread and loss our teeth regularly, •	by eating plenty of fruits and leafy vegetables, •	by using a good toothbrush and replacing it when damaged, and also using a good toothpaste •	by using a good toothbrush and replacing it when damaged, and also using a good toothpaste

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is the difference between the teeth of herbivores and carnivores?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Herbirores have flat front teeth and broad back teeth. Carnivores have sharp front teeth

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Give difference between condensation and evaporation.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The change of water into water vapour takes place due to heating. This is known as evaporation. The change of water vapour into water takes place by cooling. It is known as condensation

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is underground water? How do we get it?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Some of the rainwater seeps into the soil through tiny pores. This water seeps below rocks on the surface of the soil and reaches a solid surface. This water is called underground water. Wells, tubewells and handpumps help us to take out underground water

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: a. germs

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Why do we need fresh and clean water?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: We need clean water to drink because contaminated water can cause many diseases. Water must be purified to remove impurities and germs

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Give differences between sedimentation and decantation
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Sedimentation is the process of settling down of heavy insoluble impurities present in water, while decantation is the process of pouring out the clear water into another container

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is a reservoir?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Reservoirs are artificial or manmade lakes

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is water pollution? Explain.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Many rivers and lakes become dirty due to some human activities like bathing and washing clothes in them.  Even the factories throw their wastes carelessly into the water bodies near to which they are situated After a few years, this water becomes polluted.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Write a few advantages of a map.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Advantages of a map are : (i)	A map indicates us the way to reach our destination(ii)	It is very useful for us to find the way (iii)It is very useful for us to find the way (iv)	Map helps us to save time as they provide us with the shortest routes to our detination

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: On a map, several signs and symbols are used to show various features such as roads, railway lines, rivers, bridges, churches etc. Also, certain colours are used for certain things such as shades of blue for rivers and seas, brown for mountains, red for houses etc

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: We remain safe from diseases such as diarrhoea, dysentery, typhoid and cholera

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: How should the disposal of waste be done?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The disposal of waste should be done in a scientific way

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is the difference between biodegradable and non-biodegradable wastes?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Biodegradable wastes are those that decompose easily and mix with soil. They do not cause any harm to the environment. Nonbiodegradable wastes are those that do not decompose easily and mix with soil. They remain in the environment for years and pollute it

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is the difference between aerial and buttress root?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Aerial roots are those roots which grow downwards from the branches to soil. e.g. Banyan tree, while buttress roots are mostly large roots that grow on all sides of a tall tree. They are found in rainforests where soil is poor, so, roots do not go deep inside

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: c. special

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Traditional values are important in the __________________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: d. family

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: A family should support and nourish each member of the __________________ . without judgment.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: c. family

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Dene an immediate family.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: An immediate family is one which consists of parents and siblings.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: When do the members of an extended family meet?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Extended family member meet on special occasions like family functions, festivals, ceremonies, etc.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What do you understand by family group discussion?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The family group decisionsmaking service provides meetings involving the extended family of the child. It is also called family group discussion. The family meetings can be helpful to a child who is facing difficulties by bringing the family together to make plans and supporting those looking after them.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What do we learn from family members?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: We learn many values from our family members like : •        sharing our problems and helping one another in tough times. •        learning good values from our family. •        sharing our joys and sorrows with our relatives. •        learning to share our responsibilities with our parents.
